Articles are words that define a noun as specific or unspecific. There are two articles in English: 

	a (an) – unspecific 
	the – specific

the - comes from the word 'this'. a (an) - comes from the word 'one 1'. 

	When is 'a' and when is 'an'? 

	It's simple, if the word (noun) begins with a vowel (a, e, o, etc.), then we use an, if a consonant (b, c, d, etc.) we use a.

a car
a table
a chair
an elephant
an orange

We don't use articles when we use: 

1. numeral — (2) two cats 
2. possessive pronoun — my cat 
3. demonstrative pronouns this, that – this car/that cat 
4. negative particle NO - I have no cat

\t Subject Pronouns answer the question who? - I, you, he, she, it, we, they.
\t Object pronouns are those pronouns that receive the action in a sentence. They answer the question whom? – me, you, him, her, it, us, them.
\t Possessive pronouns show that something belongs to someone. They answer the question whose? – my, your, his, her, its, our, their.
This is my book, and that is your book.

b.u: How do we use going to?

resources.string: \t1. be going to for an intention:
I am going to visit my parents.
He is going to be a teacher.
\t2. In the Past: \n\n\tIn the past tense means that the action did not happen
I was going to invite you to the cinema, but you were busy
They were going to get married
\t3. going to for prediction: \n\n\tWe often use going to to make a prediction about the future. Our prediction is based on present evidence.
It’s going to be cold tomorrow.
He is going to be famous one day.
\t4. Order: \n\n\tThe be going to construction can be used to express an order or a strict prohibition.
You are not going to say that!
You are going to do your homework!
\t5. to go and to come: \n\n\tAfter the construction to be going to, you cannot use the verbs to go and to come:
I’m going to go to Paris
\t6. be gonna: \n\n\tSometimes when we speak quickly, GOING TO sounds like GONNA. While it is grammatically incorrect, it is used a lot in very informal English.
He is not gonna do anything

resources.string: \tHow much and How many - refers to a quantity. \n\n\tHow much is used with uncountable nouns and also used to find out the price:
How much salt should I put in?
How much does it cost to go to London?
\tHow many is only used with countable items:
How many pinches of salt should I put in?
How many students are going to London?
\tWhat is also used in questions about the profession of people, which translates as "what is your profession." This meaning of "what" should not be confused with "who", which indicates his name:
\tConjunctions are words that connect words, phrases and clauses in a sentence. \n\n\tThe main conjunctions are: and, but, or, if, when, after, before, because, so, that.

\tand – used to join two words or phrases together \n\tbut – used to introduce an added statement, usually something that is different from what you have said before \n\tor – used to connect different possibilities
Tom and I go to school together
I am from Moscow but I live in London
Do you want tea or coffee?
\tthat – used to introduce a clause that reports something or gives further information
She thinks that she is beautiful
\tbecause – for the reason that \n\tso – in this way, or like this
I don\'t smoke because it is bad
It was late, so I decided to go home
\tif – used to say that a particular thing can or will happen only after something else happens or becomes true
I will know English if I learn it
\twhen – at what time; at the time at which \n\tafter – following in time, place, or order \n\tbefore – at or during a time earlier than
I will do it when I am ready
We will go for a walk after it stops raining
\tThe verb have is one of the two most frequently used verbs in English, after "to be". Have can be used in two different functions: \n\n\t1. As a main verb, meaning “to own”:
\t2. As an auxiliary verb, which will be covered in other topics (A2)

+ 
I have 
You have 
He/She/It has 
We have 
They have 

- 
I don’t have 
You don’t have 
He/She/It doesn’t have 
We don’t have 
They don’t have
Particularly in spoken English, have as a main verb, meaning own or possess or receive can be consolidated by adding the participle got. You can say “I have a family” or “I have got a family”

I have got = I have 
You have got = You have 
He/She/It has got = He/She/It has 
We have got = We have 
They have got = They have
In this case, the negative form is used without the do particle (don’t / doesn’t) , but only by adding not after have:

- 
I haven’t got = I don’t have 
You haven’t got = You don’t have 
He/She/It hasn’t got = He/She/It doesn’t have 
We haven’t got = We don’t have 
They haven’t got = They don’t have
\tThe modal “can” is a commonly used modal verb in English. It is used to express: ability, opportunity, a request, to grant permission, to show possibility or impossibility.
\tIn the past tense “can” has the form “could”:
I could swim when I was 10
\tIn the future, “can” has no form, instead we use the form “be able to”:
I will be able to swim soon
\tFor the negative form, add not after can/could, and it is often shortened:
I can not find my key
I could not swim when I was 5
I couldn\'t swim when I was 5
In the next topic we will look at 3 more modal verbs

In this topic, we will learn the verbs “must”, “may” and “should”, they all have the same form for all persons: 

must – used to show that it is necessary or very important 
may – to say that someone has permission in a formal way 
should – used to say or ask what is the correct or best thing to do
You must listen to the teacher!

\tYou use must to indicate that you think it is very important or necessary for something to happen. \n\tMust has no future and past tense forms, therefore in these tenses it is always replaced by have to.
I will have to leave soon
\tMay can be used to describe two ideas: \n1.Possibility (in the past, present or future) \n2.Permission
\tIn the past tense may has the form might, and might can also be used in the present, and this is considered a more polite form of may:
He said you might stay here
\tIn the future, may has no form and uses the constructions be allowed to, be permitted and others depending on the passed value.
You will be allowed to stay here
\tShould is a modal verb most commonly used to make recommendations or give advice. \nIt can also be used to express obligation as well as expectation.
\tIn the past and future tense, should doesn\'t change:
There is a book on the table
\tWe use there is and there are to say that something exists.
There is a man in the room
\tThe word there should not be taken literally. This must be understood simply as it exists.
There is a book on the table
There are books on the table
\tWe use \'there is + singular\' and \'there are + plural\'.
There is not anyone in the room
There isn’t anyone in the room
\tNegative form is used with the not particle \n\n\tWe can use this construction in the past tense. To do this, simply put the verb to be (is, are) in the past tense (was, were)
There was a book on the table
There were books on the table
There will be a book on the table
\tThe quantifiers some, any and no are a kind of determiner.
Is there anything I can do for you?
\tSomeone, somebody, something: \n\nSome is an unspecified quantity.
I hope that somebody will come.
\tAnyone, anybody, anything: \n\nAny is also an unspecified quantity. It refers to \"one, some or all\". So it\'s a quantity from 1 to infinity (∞).
Do you see anything in the sky?
Does anyone want to go to the cinema?
\tNo one, nobody, nothing: \n\nNo is easy! No is ZERO (0).
\tEveryone, everybody, everything: \n\n used when referring to all the members of a group of three or more.
A lot – Much – Many \nA little – A few
\tWe use much with singular uncountable nouns and many with plural nouns, or we can use a lot of in both cases:
I always put much sugar in my tea
I always put a lot of sugar in my tea
I have many cats at home
I have a lot of cats at home
\tCountable Nouns \nCountable nouns (or count nouns) are those that refer to something that can be counted. They have both singular and plural forms:

a dog – two dogs 
a man – six men 
a girl – many girls 
a problem – many problems

\tUncountable Nouns \nUncountable nouns are substances, concepts that we cannot divide into separate elements. We cannot "count" them. For example, we cannot count "milk". We can count "bottles of milk" or "litres of milk", but we cannot count "milk" itself.

water – much water 
music – much music 
money – much money 
food – much food
\tFew and a few / Little and a little \nFew refers to countable nouns, and is used with the plural form to indicate not many persons or things. For example:
A few - we mean a small amount, but it\'s enough:
Little refers to non-countable nouns, and is used with the singular form to indicate that something exists only in a small amount or to a slight degree.
A little - we mean a small amount, but it\'s enough:
The book is on the table

Prepositions of place 

	Generally, we use at, in and on when we talk about the location of things. 

in for an ENCLOSED SPACE. Basically, when something is inside something.
at for a POINT. It shows an exact position.

Prepositions of time 
Basic prepositions of time – in, on, at 

in for MONTHS, YEARS, CENTURIES and LONG PERIODS
